abstracts.cdata!:
While the second phase of the National
            Environmental Management Project is under preparation, the
            principal lessons to be drawn from the first phase of the
            project are as follows: 1) Attention must be given to
            ensuring that the community land management plan leads
            quickly to the assumption of responsibility by
            villages/communities. 2) Community organizations should be
            given greater responsibility and strengthened so that
            communities can establish their priorities not only by type
            of investment/activity, but also in relation to a budget
            determined at the outset. It is imperative for such a
            project to help beneficiaries put together the necessary
            information that will guarantee equal access to
            project-related benefits. 3) It is important to incorporate
            the financial dimension into the natural resource management
            approach, especially for those activities that generate
            revenue, and to strengthen the capabilities of target
            communities in their respect in order to create conditions
            conducive to the long-term sustainability of project
            investments. 4) Project activities must be planned in
            realistic way. Many of the delays affecting first-phase
            activities were traceable to cumbersome procedures. It is
            necessary to institute multi-year planning and start the
            preparation of bidding and pre-qualification documentation
            well before the effectiveness date.
